content: Head of the Singapore Armed Forces The **Chief of Defence Force** is the head of the [Singapore Armed Forces](/wiki/Singapore_Armed_Forces) (SAF), who holds the rank of [Lieutenant-General](/wiki/Lieutenant-General) or [Vice-Admiral](/wiki/Vice-Admiral). The Chief of Defence Force also serves as the [aide-de-camp](/wiki/Aide-de-camp) to the [president of Singapore](/wiki/President_of_Singapore). The current Chief of Defence Force is [Aaron Beng](/wiki/Aaron_Beng). The position was created in 1974 as **Chief of the General Staff**, before changing to its current name in May 1990. The first holder of the position was [Winston Choo](/wiki/Winston_Choo). The [president of Singapore](/wiki/President_of_Singapore) has the power to appoint the Chief of Defence Force, as well as the four service chiefs in the SAF, on the advice of the [prime minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Singapore), who must consult with the [Armed Forces Council](/wiki/Singapore_Armed_Forces#Legislation) (AFC). ## Role The CDF is the operational head of the SAF, and holds a seat on the Armed Forces Council which oversees all matters pertaining to the SAF. In addition, if any of the four service chiefs—the Chief of Army, Chief of Navy, Chief of Air Force or Chief of Digital and Intelligence Service—is unable to carry out his duties, the CDF is tasked to perform those duties in addition to his own. If the CDF is unable to perform his own duties, the Minister of Defence is allowed to select one of the four service chiefs to perform the CDF's duties. The office of CDF also carries with it a position as one of three full-time [aides-de-camp](/wiki/Aide-de-camp) to the President. According to the Singapore Presidential Office website, the position entails handling the President's security and his/her social needs, in addition to other general duties. A number of powers relating to [summary trials](/wiki/Summary_(law)) for military offences is vested in the CDF. Paragraph 2, Section 62 of the Singapore Armed Forces Act states that any offence in which the accused holds the [rank](/wiki/Singapore_Armed_Forces_ranks) of Colonel or Military Expert 7 is to be referred to the CDF, who can then dismiss the charge, hold a summary trial, or pass the case on to the director of legal services of the SAF, who can in turn instruct the CDF to try the accused. As head of the SAF, the CDF often makes visits to countries with shared military interests, such as Bahrain, Japan, and Vietnam, and also occasionally hosts foreign military chiefs on official visits. ## List of officeholders (1965–1990) The role of the head of the SAF was first titled as "Director, General Staff" around 1969, and was held by Brigadier-General [T. J. D. Campbell](/wiki/T._J._D._Campbell_(brigadier)), who was previously Head of the Singapore Defence Force (1965–1966), and the [Singapore Volunteer Corps](/wiki/Singapore_Volunteer_Corps) (late 1950s–1965) before the independence of Singapore in 1965. Campbell had been acting director since around 1968. [Colonel](/wiki/Colonel) [Kirpa Ram Vij](/wiki/Kirpa_Ram_Vij) was appointed as his successor. According to sources, the position of "Director, General Staff" was considered similar to the position of the present-day CDF, and was equivalent to Chief of Army. A news report from *[The Straits Times](/wiki/The_Straits_Times)* on Campbell's death refers to him as having been "army chief." In 1974, Colonel [Winston Choo](/wiki/Winston_Choo) was appointed Director, General Staff and promoted to the rank of [Brigadier-General](/wiki/Brigadier-General). Prior to his appointment, Choo served as Head of Training and Head of Organisation and Plans at the [Ministry of Defence](/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Singapore)) (MINDEF). The title of Director, General Staff was renamed to Chief of the General Staff in 1976, and again in May 1990, the position was renamed to Chief of Defence Force. Choo was promoted to the rank of [Major-General](/wiki/Major-General) in 1978 and subsequently [Lieutenant-General](/wiki/Lieutenant-General) in 1988, when he was Chief of the General Staff. Choo retired from the SAF in 1992, after 18 years serving as the head of the SAF. Prime Minister [Lee Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew) described [Goh Keng Swee](/wiki/Goh_Keng_Swee) as the *de facto* armed forces chief of staff when the latter was Minister for Defence. Goh had been responsible for evolving the SAF while serving as Minister for Defence from 1965 to 1967. Although Campbell and Vij have both held a position of similar authority, Choo is referred to as the first CDF in a number of MINDEF publications. In the past, the position of Deputy Chief of the General Staff existed, who was tasked to "[work] with troops on the ground," but there is no deputy position for the present-day CDF in the structure of the SAF.
